data.description: Aztec Ruins has some of the best-preserved Chacoan structures of its kind. Learn more about the ancestral Pueblo people in the park's museum and explore the Aztec West great house to see exceptionally advanced architecture, original wooden beams, and a restored Great Kiva. Aztec Ruins is a deeply sacred place to many Indigenous peoples across the American Southwest. Please visit with respect.
data.directionsInfo: From Albuquerque/Bloomfield, NM: Follow Hwy 550 north into Aztec, turn left onto Highway 516, drive 3/4 mile, then turn right onto Ruins Road. Follow Ruins Road 1/2 mile to the monument. From Durango, CO: Follow Hwy 550 south into Aztec, where it will become 516. Turn right onto Ruins Road. Follow Ruins Road 1/2 mile to the monument. From Farmington, NM Follow Highway 516 east into Aztec. 1/4 mile past Lightplant Road, turn left onto Ruins Road. Follow Ruins Road 1/2 mile to the monument.

operatingHours.description: Aztec Ruins National Monument is open to the public from 7:00am-5:00pm, which includes the parking areas, archeological sites, picnic areas, and trails. The visitor center is open from 9:00am-5:00pm daily. The monument and visitor center close on Thanksgiving, Christmas, and New Year's Days. Unless there is a public program scheduled, there is no after-hours access. Vehicles are not permitted to be left in the parking lot after closing.
operatingHours.name: Hours

data.weatherInfo: Summer High temperatures range between 80°F and 99°F degrees with a few days over 100°F. Afternoon thunderstorms usually cool things down in late July and August. Fall Usually pleasant, with mild days and crisp nights. Winter Daytime temperatures range between 20°F and 50°F with cold nights that can reach 0°F. Snow is periodic, but accumulations are typically only 1-2 inches. Spring Weather is especially unpredictable: it can be windy, cold, and wet, or still, warm, and dry.
data.name: Aztec Ruins

data.description: Bandelier National Monument protects over 33,000 acres of ruggedly beautiful canyon and mesa country. Petroglyphs, dwellings carved into the soft rock cliffs, and standing masonry walls pay tribute to the early days of a culture that still survives in the surrounding communities.

emailAddresses.description: General park email for any questions about monument operations.

entranceFees.description: Pass covers all persons traveling in a single, private, non-commercial vehicle (car, truck, camper, or van up to 15 passengers). Auto passes are non-transferable and not replaced if lost or stolen.  Entrance passes do not cover camping fees.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Private Vehicle

entranceFees.description: Pass covers a single motorcycle and up to two people. Motorcycle passes are non-transferable and not replaced if lost or stolen.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: Pass covers per person entrance fee for those 16 years of age and older traveling on foot or by bicycle, or for individuals traveling together in a 16 passenger or greater vehicle as a non-commercial, organized group. Individual passes are non-transferable and not replaced if lost or stolen.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Per Person

entrancePasses.description: Valid for one year from month of purchase. Admits passholder and passengers in a single, private, non-commercial vehicle, or the pass holder plus up to 3 other people when entry is by other means (foot, bicycle). Non-transferable, non-refundable, not replaceable if lost or stolen.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Entrance - Park

data.directionsInfo: From NM285 US84 in Pojaque NM. West on NM502, West on NM4 to White rock. Then 12 miles to the monument entrance on the south side of the road. Bandelier is in a remote location, with cell service in the canyon limited to Verizon 4G only. Services like Uber and Lyft will bring you here, but there may be no way to contact a ride out. Please plan your pickup before being dropped off at Bandelier.

exceptions.name: Bandelier National Monument Closed on Christmas Day

operatingHours.description: Park is open dawn to dusk each day.
operatingHours.name: Bandelier National Monument

operatingHours.description: Tsankawi is located 14.5 miles NE of Bandelier National Monument. It is located just outside of White Rock.
operatingHours.name: Tsankawi Unit

data.weatherInfo: Spring daytime temperatures in the 70's can be followed by a snow storm with wet heavy snow and daytime temperatures in the 40's. Summers are dry with June usually being the hottest month of the year. Days in July, August and September often end with thunderstorms that can drop heavy localized rain and are often accompanied by lightning. Autumn weather is usually sunny with blue skies and warm (but not hot) days and cool nights. Winter average snowfall 25". Snow and ice can close trails and roads.
data.name: Bandelier

data.description: In 1857, businessman and transportation entrepreneur John Butterfield was awarded a contract to establish an overland mail route between the eastern United States and growing populations in the Far West. What became known as the Butterfield Overland Trail made an arcing sweep across the southern rim of the country. Stagecoaches left twice a week carrying passengers, freight, and mail.
data.directionsInfo: Those portions of the Butterfield Overland National Historic Trail authorized by Congress include nearly 3,300 miles of historic trail.

operatingHours.description: The Butterfield Overland National Historic Trail is not a clearly marked hiking trail. Instead, it is a corridor that passes through communities, urban areas, public lands, and Wilderness. The route travels across a variety of land ownerships and management, including private land. Each location varies as to the hours of operation and access. Please contact individual trail sites before your visit for more information.
operatingHours.name: Butterfield Overland National Historic Trail

images.title: Presidio Chapel of San Elizario
images.altText: A cross and bell on the roof alcove of a white stucco church.
images.caption: A site along the Butterfield Overland National Historic Trail

images.title: Old Pinery Butterfield Overland NHT
images.altText: A historic stone wall stands in ruins next to a hiking trail leading into the Guadalupe Mountains NP
images.caption: Visit the Butterfield Overland National Historic Trail to a take a step back in time.

images.title: Saguaro Forest on the Butterfield Overland NHT
images.altText: A forest of tall, multi-armed Saguaro cacti stretches out towards the horizon.
images.caption: The Butterfield Overland NHT traversed thousands of miles of desert on the delivery route.

images.title: Butterfield Station site at Picacho Village in Dona Ana County, NM
images.altText: A neighborhood street lined with single story ranch homes.
images.caption: The Butterfield Overland NHT passes through modern city neighborhoods.

images.title: El Paso Station Marker
images.altText: A large stone monument sits on the side of a historic city street with brick buildings.
images.caption: Historic El Paso, Texas offers an opportunity to visit the trail in a busy city.

data.weatherInfo: Due to the length of the trail, be sure to consult local weather sources for the region you'll be visiting. Check out the forecast with the National Weather Service and search for the area you'd like to visit: weather.gov
data.name: Butterfield Overland

data.description: Part of the 8,000 square mile Raton-Clayton Volcanic Field, Capulin Volcano showcases the volcanic geology of northeastern New Mexico. The views are spectacular day or night, with views of 4 different states from the volcanic rim and one of the darkest night skies in the country. Whether it's a quick stop or a day's trip, enjoy exploring the landscape of this unique volcano!

emailAddresses.description: General mailbox of the Capulin Volcano National Monument Interpretation and Visitor Services staff.

entranceFees.description: Admits private, non-commercial vehicle (15 passenger capacity or less) and all occupants to Capulin Volcano National Monument. The maximum size of a vehicle allowed on the Volcano Road is 26 feet in length and/or 8 feet in width. Passes may be upgraded to annual passes within 7 days of purchase.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Private Vehicle

entranceFees.description: Admits one private motorcycle and all occupants to Capulin Volcano National Monument. Capulin Volcano accepts the America the Beautiful - Federal Lands Passes (Interagency Annual, Senior, and Access passes) in place of an entrance fee. Passes may be upgraded to annual passes within 7 days of purchase.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: Admits one person arriving on foot or bicycle, or by commercial operator to Capulin Volcano National Monument.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Per Person

entranceFees.description: $10 per person for organized groups such as Scouts, Rotary, Clubs, Youth Groups, Churches, Reunions, etc. that do not qualify for an Academic Fee Waiver. Fees will not exceed the commercial fee for the same-sized vehicle. Youth 15 and under are free. Individuals or families with any valid Annual or Lifetime pass may use their pass for entry at the per person rate. The maximum size of a vehicle allowed on the Volcano Road without a permit is 26 feet in length and/or 8 feet in width.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Non-commercial Groups

entranceFees.description: Educational waivers will be provided in accordance with the Code of Federal Regulations Title 36: if the request is from "organized tours or outings conducted for educational or scientific purposes related to the resources of the area visited by bona fide institutions established for these purposes.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Education/Academic Groups

entranceFees.description: Pass is valid for the day of purchase and the next six days for a vehicle carrying the same group of passengers. A commercial tour is defined as consisting of one or more persons traveling on an itinerary that has been packaged, priced, or sold for leisure or recreational purposes by an organization that realizes financial gain through the provision of the service. Entry fees of commercial tours are based upon the total capacity of vehicles.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Sedan

entrancePasses.description: The Capulin Volcano Annual Pass has a cost of $35.00 and is valid for 12 months from the month of purchase. Admits one private vehicle and all occupants to Capulin Volcano National Monument. This pass can be purchased at the visitor center. Non-transferable and non-refundable.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Entrance - Park

data.directionsInfo: Capulin Volcano National Monument is located in northeast New Mexico. The monument is located 33 miles east of Raton, NM, and 57 miles west of Clayton, NM on NM325 3 miles north of US64. No public transportation systems serve the park.

operatingHours.description: Volcano Road Vehicle Access is open from 8:30 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. Pedestrians and Bicycles are allowed on volcano road after 4:30.
operatingHours.name: Volcano Road Volcano Top Vehicle Access

operatingHours.description: Capulin Volcano National Monument trails are open from sunrise to sunset with the exception of the night sky viewing area (visitor center overflow parking lot) which is open throughout the night. Vehicle access to the Volcano Road and the Visitor Center have separate hours. Please see their individual hours.
operatingHours.name: Capulin Volcano National Monument Trails

images.title: Capulin Volcano
images.altText: A cloud shrouded volcano rises behind a field of yellow flowers.
images.caption: Capulin Volcano in summer.

images.title: Aerial View of Capulin Volcano
images.altText: View of cinder cone volcano and the road leading to the top of the volcano as seen from the air.
images.caption: Capulin Volcano is a classic example of a cinder cone. The crater is approximately 130 m (420 ft) deep and 440 m (1,450 ft) across. The base of the mountain is 6 km (4 mi) in circumference. Volcano Road spirals up the volcano, providing panoramic views.

images.title: Nature Trail at Capulin Volcano
images.altText: A shaded bench on the side of a paved nature trail wending through juniper trees and grasses.
images.caption: A paved nature trail at Capulin Volcano NM.

images.title: Volcano Road
images.altText: Layers of rock are visible in the steep hillside along a road.
images.caption: Layers of volcanic material can be seen in the Volcano Road that takes visitors to the top of Capulin Volcano.

images.title: Capulin Volcano-Best Example of a Cinder Cone in North America
images.altText: View of a cinder cone volcano covered with grasses, small trees, and other plants.
images.caption: Although Capulin Mountain is considered no longer active, because its excellent condition, the cinder cone is considered one of the best and most accessible examples of a cinder cone in North America.

data.weatherInfo: Elevations range from 7247 feet at the park visitor center to 8182 feet on the crater rim trail. Summers usually have mild temperatures with highs averaging in the low to mid 80s F/30C with occasional afternoon thunderstorms. Winters average from 40F/5C to 50F/10C, but temperatures vary. Snowfall is most common from December into April and may cause temporary closures of the volcano road. Sunny winter days are beautiful days to be in the park. Check weather conditions before visiting.
data.name: Capulin Volcano

data.description: High ancient sea ledges, deep rocky canyons, flowering cactus, and desert wildlife—treasures above the ground in the Chihuahuan Desert. Hidden beneath the surface are more than 119 caves—formed when sulfuric acid dissolved limestone leaving behind caverns of all sizes.

entranceFees.description:
A timed entry reservation must be purchased to access Carlsbad Cavern. In addition, an entry pass must be purchased at the visitor center.

Time entry reservations ensure a more enjoyable experience and helps to protect the cave formations.
entranceFees.title: Timed Entry Reservation - Location

entranceFees.description: Entrance fee provides access to Carlsbad Cavern by elevator and hiking in. Ranger-guided tours are an additional fee and can be reserved on recreation.gov.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Per Person

data.directionsInfo: To access the park's only entrance road, New Mexico Highway 7, turn north from US Hwy 62/180 at White's City, NM, which is 20 miles (32 km) southwest of Carlsbad, NM and 145 miles (233 km) northeast of El Paso, TX. The entrance road stretches a scenic seven miles (11.3 km) from the park gate at White's City to the visitor center and cavern entrance. The address for the park's visitor center is 727 Carlsbad Caverns Hwy, Carlsbad, NM, 88220, located 27 miles (43 km) from the town of Carlsbad.

operatingHours.description: Carlsbad Caverns National Park is open 24-hours a day. Visitor center hours and cave tour schedule vary throughout the year.
operatingHours.name: Hours

images.caption: Yucca blooming

data.weatherInfo: Carlsbad Caverns National Park is located in the Chihuahuan Desert in southeast New Mexico. Summers are hot with temperatures between 90°F (32°C) and low 100s °F (38°C). Windy conditions and mild temperatures are common in early spring (March-May) with frequent rain in early fall (August-September). This part of the country also sees cold temperatures in the winter with occasional snow and icy conditions. Most days, the park is enveloped by a gorgeous blue sky with very few clouds, 278 sunny days a year!
data.name: Carlsbad Caverns

data.description: Explore the monumental structures and breathtaking landscape at Chaco, a thriving regional center for the ancestral Pueblo people from 850 to 1250 CE (Common Era), through hiking & biking trails, ranger guided tours & programs, and more. Chaco Canyon is a sacred and deeply personal place for many Indigenous peoples throughout the Southwest. Please visit with respect.

entranceFees.description: This fee allows all persons traveling in one private, non-commercial vehicle (car/truck/van) to enter the park to visit for up to 7 days from the date of purchase.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Private Vehicle

entranceFees.description: This fee allows a single individual traveling on foot, bicycle, or as individuals traveling together in a vehicle as a non-commercial, organized group to enter the park to visit for up to 7 days from the date of purchase.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Per Person

entranceFees.description: This fee allows one motorcycle to enter the park to visit for up to 7 days from the date of purchase.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: This fee for commercial entrance is charged per vehicle and based on the capacity of the vehicle.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Van

entranceFees.description: This fee for commercial entrance is charged per vehicle and based on the capacity of the vehicle.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Motor Coach

entranceFees.description: Non-commercial groups are charged per vehicle and based on the capacity of the vehicle. For vehicles with a seating capacity of 15 or fewer, the fee is $25. For vehicles with a seating capacity of 16 or more, the fee is $15/person up to the commercial fee rate. Interagency passes may be used for entry in lieu of the $15/person fee.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Non-commercial Groups

entranceFees.description: If you represent an academic institution, you may be eligible for a fee waiver. Download and complete the Academic Fee Waiver and mail it to the park at least two weeks prior to your intended visit. We will notify you of the approval or disapproval of your application before your arrival. Please call 505-786-7014 for any additional questions about this process.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Education/Academic Groups

entranceFees.description: This fee for commercial entrance is charged per vehicle and based on the capacity of the vehicle.

data.directionsInfo: Your journey into Chaco Canyon will take you through private tribal lands. Please be respectful of our tribal neighbors and their livestock and leave no trace of your journey on their lands. Chaco Canyon is located in northwestern New Mexico. The park can only be accessed by driving on dirt roads. Road conditions can be rough or impassable. Please call in advance for updates.

operatingHours.description: All hiking trails and archaeological sites are open from 7am until 9:00pm from May 1-October 31. The visitor center is open from 9:00am-5:00pm daily. At 8:30 PM, you must be leaving or if you are camping, you need to be back in the campground.
operatingHours.name: Chaco Culture National Historical Park

images.title: Fajada Butte
images.altText: Fajada Butte's silhoutte shown under a timelapse image of stars appearing in a vibrant circle above.
images.caption: Chaco Culture National Historical Park is an International Dark Sky Park.

images.title: Chaco Culture NHP Entrance Sign
images.altText: The entrance sign to Chaco Culture made out of sandstone and showing Fajada Butte through a window.
images.caption: Welcome to Chaco Culture National Historical Park!

images.title: Sandstone Walls
images.altText: Colorful sandstone walls with two open sections in the middle that look like doorways.
images.caption: Most walls seen at Chaco Culture NHP are close to 1,000 years old.

images.title: Raven
images.altText: A raven perched on the side of a canyon wall.
images.caption: Observe many ravens while visiting Chaco Culture NHP.

images.title: Pueblo Bonito
images.altText: An aerial view of the Pueblo Bonito great house showing many rooms and circular kivas.
images.caption: Pueblo Bonito is the largest great house within Chaco Canyon.

images.title: Chacoan Jars
images.altText: A series of 4 Chacoan jars replicated in the same black on white style that was excavated long ago.
images.caption: Chaco Culture National Historical Park is home to impressive pottery built by the ancestral Pueblo people.

data.weatherInfo: Summer highs are typically in the 80s to mid-90s. Thunderstorms can produce heavy localized downpours and sudden dramatic drops in temperatures. Winter temperatures will drop to well below freezing most nights. If you plan to camp in the winter, prepare for nighttime temperatures in the teens or lower. Spring and fall are great times to visit with more moderate temperatures, but unexpected storms can change things dramatically. Monitor local weather forecasts.
data.name: Chaco Culture

data.fullName: El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro National Historic Trail
data.description: Travel along El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro National Historic Trail to experience and learn from a complicated legacy of 300 years of conflict, cooperation, and cultural exchange between a variety of empires—European and non-European alike.
data.directionsInfo: You can visit many sites along El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro National Historic Trail over the 404-mile U.S. historic route (with thousands of additional miles in Mexico) that crosses New Mexico and Texas.

operatingHours.description: El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro National Historic Trail is not a clearly marked hiking trail. Instead it is a route that passes through communities, urban areas, public lands, and Wilderness. The route travels across a variety of land ownerships and management, including private land. Beyond the United States, the trail reaches Mexico City, Mexico. Each location varies as to the hours of operations and access. Please contact individual trail sites before your visit for more information.
operatingHours.name: El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro National Historic Trail

addresses.line2: El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro National Historic Trail
El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro National Historic Trail

images.title: Kuaua Ruin in Coronado Historic Site, Bernalillo, New Mexico
images.altText: tan-colored pueblo Indian ruins with blue sky and three people
images.caption: The Tiwa pueblo of Kuaua lies in ruin at Coronado Historic Site. The site includes a rebuilt kiva that displays reproductions of original murals adorning its walls. Be sure to go to the visitor center where some of the original murals are displayed.

images.title: El Rancho de las Golondrinas, La Cienega, New Mexico
images.altText: adobe buildings including two beehive-looking ovens with people in a courtyard
images.caption: El Rancho de las Golondrinas was a historic paraje (stopping place) along El Camino Real. “The ranch of the swallows” dates from the early 1700s, and is now being used as a living history museum.

images.title: Jornada del Muerto, County Roads A013 & E070, Sierra & Doña Ana Counties, New Mexico
images.altText: shrubby desert scene with people walking under a cloud-filled sky
images.caption: Walk in the footsteps of settlers from the 1600s who had to walk along this dreaded yet unavoidable section of El Camino Real: Jornada del Muerto or Dead Man’s Journey.

images.title: Fort Selden Historic Site, Radium Springs, New Mexico
images.altText: fort ruins in the sunlight with cottonwood trees on the left
images.caption: Fort Selden was built near the town of Las Cruces in 1865 and housed troops for 25 years. The visitor center offers exhibits on frontier military life during the fort’s heyday and the grounds are self-guided.

images.title: Presidio Chapel of San Elizario, Mission Trail, El Paso, Texas
images.altText: large white chapel under blue sky
images.caption: Spanish troops built a presidio (fort) and chapel at this site during the 1780s to protect settlements in the lower Río Grande Valley downstream from El Paso, Texas.

data.weatherInfo: Due to the length of El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro National Historic Trail, be sure to consult local weather sources for the region you'll be visiting. Check out the forecast with the National Weather Service and search for the area you'd like to visit: weather.gov
data.name: El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro

multimedia.title: Casa San Ysidro – Place to visit on El Camino National Historic Trail

data.description: The richly diverse volcanic landscape of El Malpais (el-mal-pie-EES) offers solitude, recreation, and adventure. Explore incredible geologic features such as lava flows, cinder cones, lava tube caves, and sandstone bluffs. While some may see a desolate environment, people have been adapting to and living in this extraordinary terrain for generations. Come visit the land of frozen fire!
data.directionsInfo: No roads exist through El Malpais National Monument. To explore the east side of the park, take exit 89 off I-40 and head south on Highway 117. To explore the north side of the park, take exit 81 off I-40 and head south on Highway 53. To reach the visitor center, take exit 85 off I-40 in Grants, New Mexico. After you exit, head south on Santa Fe Ave and continue straight over the freeway overpass. Take a left at the entrance sign for El Malpais Visitor Center and continue 300 yards to the parking lot.

operatingHours.description:
El Malpais National Monument is open 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, with the following exceptions:

- Sandstone Bluffs Overlook and the west Zuni-Acoma Trail parking lot are open from sunrise to sunset.
- El Malpais Visitor Center and parking area is open daily from 9:00 am to 5:00 pm. Winter hours may vary. The visitor center is closed on Thanksgiving Day, December 25th, and January 1st.
- El Malpais Emergency Operations Center is currently closed to the public.
operatingHours.name: El Malpais National Monument

images.title: Sandstone Bluffs Overlook
images.altText: Yellow sandstone cliff at sunset with dark lava field in background
images.caption: Sandstone Bluffs Overlook offers a beautiful view over the vast volcanic landscape of El Malpais.

images.title: Wildflowers on the El Calderon Trail
images.altText: Hiking in Summer
images.caption: Enjoy a stroll along the El Calderon Trail to view beautiful wildflowers in summer.

images.title: Sandstone Bluffs Overlook
images.altText: Summer at Sandstone Bluffs Overlook
images.caption: A vast expanse of lava fields as seen from Sandstone Bluffs Overlook

images.title: View from El Calderon
images.altText: Summer view from El Calderon cinder cone
images.caption: A hike to the top of El Calderon cinder cone offers one a view of the entire monument.

images.title: Lava Tube Cave
images.altText: Lava Tube caving at El Malpais
images.caption: Explore lava tube caving at El Malpais National Monument

data.weatherInfo: As a general rule, daily temperatures swing roughly 30 (F) from night lows to afternoon highs. Summer is sunny and hot with monsoon rain storms and an average high of 80 (F). Winter is cool, sunny, with potential snow storms and an average high of 45 (F). Spring and fall are generally dry with the occasional storm rain and/or snow storm. For more information on weather and current weather conditions visit https://www.nps.gov/elma/planyourvisit/weather.htm
data.name: El Malpais

data.description: Imagine the refreshment of finding water after days of dusty travel. A reliable waterhole hidden at the base of a sandstone bluff made El Morro (the headland) a popular campsite for hundreds of years. Here, ancestral Puebloans, Spanish, and American travelers carved over 2,000 signatures, dates, messages, and petroglyphs. Make El Morro National Monument a stopping point on your travels.
data.directionsInfo: From Albuquerque, NM, or from the east: take Interstate 40 west to Grants. At exit 81, go south on Highway 53 for 42 miles to El Morro National Monument. From Flagstaff, AZ, or from the west: take Interstate 40 east to Gallup. At exit 20, go south on Highway 602 for about 31 miles. Turn east (left) onto Highway 53. El Morro is 25 more miles.

operatingHours.description:
Summer Hours (May 24, 2025 - October 18, 2025) Park visitor center and trails open 7 days/week.

Trail access begins at 9:00 am. Last admittance to the Headland Trail is at 3:00 pm MT. Last admittance to the Inscription Loop Trail is at 4:00 pm MT. There is no access to park trails once the visitor center closes at 5:00 pm.

Winter Hours (October 19, 2025 - May 23, 2026). Visitor center and trails open 5 days/week. Closed Tuesdays and Wednesdays. 

Closed Thanksgiving Day, December 25, and January 1.
operatingHours.name: El Morro National Monument

images.title: El Morro with Sunflowers
images.altText: El Morro with Sunflowers
images.caption: El Morro with Sunflowers

images.title: Pool at El Morro
images.altText: Pool at El Morro
images.caption: A drinking hole for visitors for hundreds of years, the pool at El Morro has significant cultural and historical value.

images.title: Trail at El Morro
images.altText: Trail at El Morro
images.caption: Constructed by the CCC, the historic headland trail at El Morro offers visitors great views and the archaeological site of Atsinna.

images.title: Atsinna Pueblo
images.altText: Atsinna Pueblo
images.caption: Atsinna Pueblo sits atop the headland at El Morro

images.title: El Morro in snow
images.altText: Headland in Snow
images.caption: El Morro blanketed with snow

data.weatherInfo: At an elevation of 7,219 feet (2200 meters) winters can be cold and snowy. Summers are warm with afternoon thunder showers from mid-July through mid-September. Trails can close unexpectedly due to severe weather. Average snowfall: 40 inches per year. Average precipitation (snowmelt and rain): 16 inches per year. Warmest month: July, with average highs of 84 degrees and lows of 52 degrees. Coldest months: December and January, with average lows of 14-15 degrees, and average highs of 44-45 degrees.
data.name: El Morro

data.description: Exposed to the wind, within a sweeping valley of short grass prairie, and along the eroded Santa Fe Trail, lie the adobe walled ruins of the largest 19th century military fort in the region. From 1851 to 1891, Fort Union functioned as an agent of change, desired or not, in the New Mexico Territory and throughout the Southwest.
data.directionsInfo: Fort Union National Monument is located in the Northeastern portion of the state of New Mexico. 8 miles off of Interstate I-25 on State Highway NM 161. New Mexico: From Albuquerque (156 miles), Santa Fe (94 miles) or Las Vegas, NM (28 miles) take I-25 North, exit 366 at Watrous, 8 miles on NM 161. Colorado: From Denver (313 miles), Colorado Springs (243 miles) or Raton (95 miles) take I-25 South, exit 366 at Watrous, 8 miles on NM 161.

operatingHours.description:
The monument grounds and visitor center are generally open 7 days a week, from 8:00 AM - 4:00 PM.

The monument is closed Thanksgiving Day, Christmas Day, New Year's Day.
operatingHours.name: Fort Union National Monument Operating Hours

images.credit: Ron Harvey - Fort Union National Monument
images.title: Big Skies Over Officers Row
images.altText: Panorama of Officers Row
images.caption: Blue skies and billowing clouds frequently add to the incredible viewshed that surrounds the monument grounds.

images.credit: Ron Harvey - Fort Union National Monument
images.title: Freezing Fog in Mechanics Corral
images.altText: Wagons encrusted in frost
images.caption: One of the most photographed areas of the monument, the Mechanics Corral onced serviced wagons that travelled along the Santa Fe Trail.

images.credit: Ron Harvey - Fort Union National Monument
images.title: Sunflower in Enlisted Barracks
images.altText: Sunflower in Enlisted Barracks
images.caption: Located deep within the Mora Valley, Fort Union National Monument contains a vast array of plant and animal life.

images.title: Remnants of the Past
images.altText: Moon in sky above adobe remnants
images.caption: Located on the monument grounds is the world's largest collection of Territorial-Style adobe remanants.

images.credit: Ron Harvey - Fort Union National Monument
images.title: Fort Union NM Visitor Center
images.altText: Fort Union Visitor Center Sign
images.caption: Completed in 1960, the Visitor Center at Fort Union was one of the first built during the "MIssion 66" program for the National Park Service. It was designed by the internationally known architect Cecil Doty.

data.weatherInfo: Fort Union is situated at 6,760 feet above sea level. Daytime temperatures between June and September may exceed 90 degrees Fahrenheit. Winter temperatures often drop below 32 degrees Fahrenheit. Temperatures may vary within 50 degrees in a 24-hour period. During the winter, it is not uncommon for the temperatures to drop below 0°F (-18°C.) During the summer, expect high temperatures, intense sunlight and extremely low humidity.
data.name: Fort Union

data.description: For thousands of years, groups of nomads used the caves above Cliff Dweller Creek as temporary shelter. In the late 1200s, people of the agricultural Mogollon (Southern Ancestral Pueblo) culture made it a home. They built rooms, crafted pottery and raised children in the cliff dwellings for one or two generations. By approximately 1300, the Mogollon had moved on, leaving the walls behind.
data.directionsInfo: Passenger vehicles can drive north of Silver City, New Mexico to the monument on NM Hwy 15. The 46 mile trip can take up to two hours due to the narrow and mountainous curving nature of the road. RVs and vehicles pulling trailers should NOT use NM Hwy 15. From Silver City, take US Highway 180 to Santa Clara. Turn left onto NM Hwy 152 and drive to San Lorenzo. At San Lorenzo, turn left onto NM Hwy 35 and follow it to its termination at NM Hwy 15. Turn right on NM Hwy 15 and follow signs to the park.

operatingHours.description: The National Monument and Visitor Center are open all year and are closed only for Thanksgiving Day (the 4th Thursday of November), Christmas Day (December 25) and New Year's Day (January 1).
operatingHours.name: Gila Cliff Dwellings National Monument

operatingHours.description: At the Trailhead Bookstore, you will find our park store operated by the Western National Parks Association. Many items related to the park, the Gila Wilderness, and the Continental Divide Trail are available, as well as souvenirs and American Indian crafts. Park staff are available to answer questions and help plan visits. Come discover your heritage and your public lands.
operatingHours.name: WNPA Bookstore

images.title: Winter Solstice Sunrise at Gila Cliff Dwellings
images.altText: Sunrise view of Gila Cliff Dwellings with brilliant sky.
images.caption: Visitors enjoy panoramic views of the canyon and dwellings at Gila Cliff Dwellings.

images.title: Looking Back in Time
images.altText: View of Mogollon dwelling rooms within a cave.
images.caption: Tularosa Phase Mogollon people made these caves their home in the late 1200's.

images.title: A Place to Call Home
images.altText: Cliff Dwellings walls and rooms with narrow catwalk
images.caption: Most of the dwellings walls are original. Some even preserve a builder's fingerprints that are over 700 years old.

images.title: Mogollon Cliff Dwelling with T Door
images.altText: Exterior view of Mogollon Cliff Dwelling
images.caption: The T-shaped door suggests trade between Mogollon and Ancestral Puebloan.

images.title: View of the Gila River Valley near Gila Cliff Dwellings NM
images.altText: Distant view of Gila river valley and mountains beyond.
images.caption: The Oldest Wilderness Area in the United States Awaits.

images.title: Gila National Forest Approach to Gila National Monument in Winter
images.altText: Light snowfall on red rock cliffs along river.
images.caption: Winter wonderland along the Gila River

images.title: Eroded Cliffs Along the Gila River
images.altText: Eroded cliffs reflecting off a river
images.caption: As the first designated Wilderness Area, the Gila offers endless opportunites peaceful reflection.

data.weatherInfo: Weather is extremely variable. Summers are usually around 90° F. but approach 100° F. Winters have occasional snow or temperatures near 0° F. Thunderstorms are common in the summer and early fall, usually in the afternoon. https://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lat=33.2296&lon=-108.2639#.YUX0_SuSmUk
data.name: Gila Cliff Dwellings

data.description: The Manhattan Project is one of the most transformative events of the 20th century. It ushered in the nuclear age with the development of the world’s first atomic bombs. Most of this development took place in three secret communities located in Hanford, WA, Los Alamos, NM and Oak Ridge, TN. Today, you can visit these three sites that make up Manhattan Project National Historical Park.
data.directionsInfo: Manhattan Project National Historical Park is located in three states: New Mexico, Tennessee, and Washington. For more information on accessing each of these three units, visit our Directions & Transportation page.

operatingHours.description:
Access to the Hanford B Reactor is by tour only. Separate tours of the Historic Sites are also offered. 
For more information about tours of the B Reactor, visit http://manhattanprojectbreactor.hanford.gov/. 
For more information about tours of the historic sites, visit http://tours.hanford.gov/HistoricTours/.
operatingHours.name: Hanford Visitor Center

operatingHours.description: While there is currently no public access to the Department of Energy facilities in Los Alamos, walking tours are available in the town of Los Alamos. The Los Alamos Visitor Center is open Friday through Monday, 10 am to 3 pm.
operatingHours.name: Los Alamos Visitor Center

operatingHours.description: The Oak Ridge Visitor Center is located within the Children's Museum of Oak Ridge. Here you are able to speak with National Park Service rangers, watch a short film on the Manhattan Project, and get literature on Manhattan Project-related historic sites throughout Oak Ridge. Visitor Center services are limited on Sundays, but brochures, maps, and site films are available.
operatingHours.name: Oak Ridge Visitor Center

addresses.line1: National Park Service, Manhattan Project National Historical Park
National Park Service, Manhattan Project National Historical Park

images.title: Oppenheimer and Groves at Trinity Test Site
images.altText: Historic photo of two men standing next to a mangled piece of metal equipment in the desert.
images.caption: J. Robert Oppenheimer and Gen. Leslie Groves at the Trinity Test Site.

images.title: Hanford B Reactor
images.altText: Gray factory building like stacked boxes with single taller smokestack beneath cloudy blue skies.
images.caption: The B Reactor, located along the Columbia River in Washington, was the world’s first full scale nuclear reactor.

images.title: Hanford Hike Through Time
images.altText: Uniformed park ranger talks animatedly to visitors on a hillside overlooking a sprawling urban area.
images.caption: A hike with a Hanford park ranger can lead to new insights and perspectives of the local area.

images.title: Los Alamos Slotin Building
images.altText: Two-story white house with two small windows, a single door, and flat roof stands in a gravel lot.
images.caption: Historic structures endure at Los Alamos, preserving the legacies and untold stories of this important chapter in world history.

images.title: Los Alamos Ashley Pond Walk
images.altText: Uniformed park ranger points to distance of fountain and trees as visitors sit enraptured.
images.caption: Park rangers engage visitors in several locations across the Los Alamos area.

images.title: Oak Ridge X-10 Control Panel
images.altText: Wooden chair sits amid light blue paneling covered in dials, meters, screens, and buttons.
images.caption: Many locations at the Oak Ridge site can be accessed through guided tours coordinated by the US Department of Energy.

images.title: Oak Ridge Family Fun
images.altText: Uniformed park ranger stands with youth along path lined with green broadleaved trees.
images.caption: An outing with Oak Ridge park rangers is fun for the whole family.

data.weatherInfo: The Manhattan Project National Historical Park has units in Hanford, WA, Los Alamos, NM, and Oak Ridge, TN. Check local weather conditions at each unit before you visit.
data.name: Manhattan Project

data.description: Follow the routes of mule pack trains across the Southwest on the Old Spanish National Historic Trail between Santa Fe, New Mexico, and Los Angeles, California. New Mexican traders moved locally produced merchandise across what are now six states to exchange for mules and horses.
data.directionsInfo: You can visit many sites of the Old Spanish National Historic Trail over the 2,700-mile historic route that crosses 6 states.

operatingHours.description: There are many places of history and commemoration on the Old Spanish National Historic Trail to visit. Museums, interpretive centers, and historic sites provide information and interpretation. Please contact each site before you go to obtain current information on closures, changes in hours, and fees.
operatingHours.name: Old Spanish National Historic Trail

images.title: Santa Rosa de Lima de Abiquiú, Abiquiú, New Mexico
images.altText: crumbling adobe structure with blue sky
images.caption: Santa Rosa de Lima de Abiquiú provided a way station for travelers along the Old Spanish Trail in the 1800s. It is privately owned by the Archdiocese of Santa Fe.

images.title: Rio Chama River, Abiquiú, New Mexico
images.altText: hikers walk beside a river with cottonwoods alongside the river
images.caption: This section of the Rio Chama River, tributary of the Rio Grande, is located about six miles north of Abiquiú, New Mexico and flows through the Carson National Forest.

images.title: Sierra Blanca, San Luis Valley, Colorado
images.altText: desert scrub in foreground, spiky mountains in background, clouds
images.caption: Sierra Blanca is a prominent mountain in the Sangre de Cristo Range along San Luis Valley on Highway 17. Locating landmarks were essential to traveling the Old Spanish Trail.

images.title: San Rafael Swell, Utah
images.altText: desert scenery, dead tree, blue sky with puffy coulds
images.caption: The San Rafael Swell is a huge craggy geologic feature (an anticline), about 75 miles by 40 miles, located in south-central Utah approximately 30 miles west of Green River.

images.title: Virgin River Canyon, Arizona
images.altText: a river carves through the landscape, greenery in the foreground, mountains and redrock backdrop
images.caption: This section of the Virgin River Canyon Recreation Area is off Interstate 15 about 20 miles southwest of St. George, Utah and about 20 miles northeast of Mesquite, Nevada

images.title: Old Spanish Trail segment, Nevada
images.altText: rocky trail through desert with yucca, mountain in the background
images.caption: This trail segment is 5.25 miles, and is part of the Old Spanish Trail/Mormon Road Historic District, outside Blue Diamond, Clark County, Nevada.

images.title: Mojave Road, California
images.altText: trail through desert scrub with Joshua trees, mountains in the distance, puffy clouds
images.caption: Old Spanish Trail travelers used this section of the historic Mojave Road is within Mojave National Preserve.

data.weatherInfo: Due to the length of Old Spanish National Historic Trail, be sure to consult local weather sources for the region you'll be visiting. Check out the forecast with the National Weather Service and search for the area you'd like to visit: weather.gov
data.name: Old Spanish

multimedia.title: Los Luceros Historic Site – Place to visit on the Old Spanish National Historic Trail
Amargosa Canyon Trail - Place to visit on the Old Spanish National Historic Trail
Late Night Trailhead – Place to visit on the Old Spanish National Historic Trail

data.description: Pecos is a natural and cultural crossroads through which hunters, gatherers, traders, missionaries, immigrants, soldiers, ranchers, and other travelers passed and lived. Follow in their footsteps and imagine Pecos through the centuries. Visit sites where cultural demonstrations and traditional practices continue today - a living legacy of the people who passed this way. At Pecos, past is present.
data.directionsInfo: Pecos National Historical Park is 25 miles east of Santa Fe, New Mexico off of Interstate 25. Visitors travelling north on I-25: take exit 299 on to HWY 50 to Pecos village and south two miles on State Road 63. Those travelling south on I-25: take exit 307 and proceed four miles north to the Park on State Road 63.

operatingHours.description: Pecos National Historical Park is open daily from 8:00 am to 4:30 pm. The park is not open on Thanksgiving Day, Christmas Day, or New Years Day.
operatingHours.name: General Park Hours

images.title: Mission Church and Kiva
images.altText: Church and preservation workers in distance, kiva in foreground.jpg (943 kb)
images.caption: Clouds gather on a summer day at the mission church

images.title: Mission from front
images.altText: An adobe building under cloudy skies.
images.caption: As the largest remaining building from the 1700s, the Mission Church draws in folks on the Ancestral Sites Trail every day.

images.title: Civil War Encampment
images.altText: Reenactors prepare a cannon under a mesa and blue skies.
images.caption: Civil War Encampment reenactors ready a black powder cannon demonstration in front of Glorieta Mesa,

images.title: Feast Day at Pecos Pueblo
images.altText: A line of people walk past adobe bricks, trees, and the road.
images.caption: The Feast Day of Pecos Pueblo draws in hundreds from Jemez Pueblo, Pecos, and the surrounding communities each year.

images.title: Winter at Pecos
images.altText: Snow covers a landscape with trees and mesas.
images.caption: Winter at Pecos can have snow blanketing the pass and local area.

data.weatherInfo: Pecos National Historical Park is located at nearly 7,000 feet in altitude in the high desert region of Northern New Mexico. Please know your limits at this high desert altitude. We recommend that you wear clothing appropriate to the season, bring plenty of water, stop for a snack or lunch at one of the picnic tables, wear comfortable shoes, and put on plenty of sunscreen. Specific daily Pecos weather information may be accessed at this link: http://www.nps.gov/peco/planyourvisit/weather.htm.
data.name: Pecos

data.description: Petroglyph National Monument protects one of the largest petroglyph sites in North America, featuring designs and symbols carved onto volcanic rocks by Native Americans and Spanish settlers 400 to 700 years ago. These images are a valuable record of cultural expression and hold profound spiritual significance for contemporary Native Americans and for the descendants of the early Spanish settlers.
data.directionsInfo: GPS: Lat: 35.139 Long: -106.711 From Interstate 40, take the Unser Blvd. exit (#154) proceed north 3 miles to Western Trail. Turn left or west onto Western Trail and follow road to the Visitor Information Center parking lot. From Interstate 25, take the Paseo del Norte exit (#232) and proceed west to Coors Road exit south (must be in center lane to veer left at the Y). Proceed south on Coors Road to Western Trail. Turn right or west onto Western Trail and follow road to the Visitor Info Center parking lot.

operatingHours.description: Staffed by our partner, the City of Albuquerque Open Space, this developed trail system consists of 3 short, paved trails with trail markers. Full-service restroom facility, picnic tables, shaded seating areas and a shaded patio area. See up to 100 petroglyphs in one hour if you walk all 3 trails. Last entry is at 4:00 pm daily and all visitors are swept out at 4:30 pm sharp. Pets not allowed on the petroglyph viewing trails. Trails are not accessible for wheelchairs or strollers.
operatingHours.name: Boca Negra Canyon

exceptions.name: Rinconada Canyon Parking Lot closed on Thanksgiving Day

operatingHours.description: An undeveloped trail system, no water or services are provided. A 2.2-mile round trip trail where up to 300 petroglyphs can be viewed, especially in the back of the canyon. The natural earth surface trail is easy to moderate to walk. Picnic tables are located in the parking lot. A vault toilet is available. No water. Open for hiking on holidays. After hours parking is available outside of the gated parking lot. Lock your vehicle, secure your valuables, do not leave any items visible. Leashed pets allowed.
operatingHours.name: Rinconada Canyon

operatingHours.description: Nestled in the northernmost tip of the monument, this undeveloped trail system is a 6.5-mile drive from the information center. The petroglyph viewing trail is 1.5 miles in and out. No water, no restroom, no amenities available. See up to 400 petroglyphs. Leashed pets allowed, pick-up waste & put in trash can. The non-gated parking lot is located off Golf Course Rd. at Jill Patricia St. (behind the Valvoline Motor Oil station, use Google maps). Stop by the information center for a free trail guide.
operatingHours.name: Piedras Marcadas Canyon

exceptions.name: Volcanoes Day Use Area Parking Lot Closed on Thanksgiving Day

operatingHours.description: No petroglyph viewing available. One to four miles of hiking trails lead you to the scenic overlook or around the bases of the cinder cones. Hiking to the tops of cones is prohibited. No water available. Vault restroom, benches, and trash cans available. Leashed pets allowed. Owners must pick-up waste & place in trash can. Parking lot is located off Atrisco Vista Blvd. (I-40 exit #149) approximately 4.7 miles north of Interstate 40. Stop by the information center for a free trail guide.
operatingHours.name: Volcanoes Day Use Area

addresses.line2: Unser Blvd. NW at Western Trail

images.title: Handprint petroglyphs in Piedras Marcadas Canyon
images.altText: Petroglyphs on dark boulders with a cloudy sky.
images.caption: Handprints and other petroglyphs on boulders at Piedras Marcadas.

images.title: Hawk petroglyph at Mesa Prieta
images.altText: A petroglyph of a hawk on a dark boulder with a cloudy sky and mountains in the background.
images.caption: A petroglyph of a hawk at Mesa Prieta. It can be visited from the South Point trailhead.

images.title: Desert mammal petroglyph
images.altText: Petroglyph of a small mammal along the Mesa Point Trail in Boca Negra Canyon.
images.caption: Petroglyph of a small mammal along the Mesa Point Trail in Boca Negra Canyon.

images.title: Macaw petroglyph
images.altText: Petroglyph of a macaw parrot along the Macaw Trail in Boca Negra Canyon.
images.caption: Petroglyph of a macaw parrot along the Macaw Trail in Boca Negra Canyon.

images.title: Coyote and rattlesnake petroglyphs in Rinconada Canyon
images.altText: Petroglyph imagery of a coyote and rattlesnake in Rinconada Canyon.
images.caption: Petroglyph imagery of a coyote and rattlesnake in Rinconada Canyon.

images.title: Petroglyph of grazing sheep in Rinconada Canyon
images.altText: Petroglyph panel of sheep grazing in Rinconada Canyon.
images.caption: Petroglyph panel of sheep grazing in Rinconada Canyon.

images.title: Snow Dusted Cinder Cones
images.altText: Winter scene of snow covered cinder cones at the Volcanoes Day Use Area.
images.caption: Winter scene of snow covered cinder cones at the Volcanoes Day Use Area.

images.title: Coyote and rattlesnake petroglyphs
images.altText: Petroglyphs of a coyote and a rattlesnake on a dark boulder.
images.caption: These petroglyphs could possibly depict a coyote and a rattlesnake, two of the more commonly seen animals at the monument.

images.title: Bird Petroglyph
images.altText: A petroglyph of a bird on a dark boulder.
images.caption: A petroglyph of a bird at Rinconada Canyon.

images.title: Bird and Footprint Petroglyphs
images.altText: Petroglyphs of a bird and a footprint on a dark boulder.
images.caption: Petroglyphs of a bird and a footprint at Piedras Marcadas Canyon.

images.title: The Volcanoes of Petroglyph
images.altText: A view of the cinder cones covered by dormant grasses.
images.caption: A line of cinder cone volcanoes at the Volcanoes Day Use Area.

data.weatherInfo: Altitude approx. 5000 ft. Usually sunny and dry, with low relative humidity. Winter temperatures range from 40 to 50 degrees F. Summer temperatures range from 88-99 degrees F. 278 days of sunshine per year. Spring can be windy with 20 to 30 mph sustained winds which can produce periods of blowing sand and dust. For current weather forecast, Google Albuquerque weather.
data.name: Petroglyph

data.description: Tucked away in the middle of New Mexico you’ll find Salinas Pueblo Missions National Monument. Its three distinct sites offer a glimpse into a unique time in history—a time entrenched with cultural borrowing, conflict and struggles. These sites continue to stand as reminders of the Spanish and Pueblo peoples’ early encounters and prompt exploration of today’s interactions among different people.
data.directionsInfo: Reach the Mountainair Headquarters by taking I-25 south from Albuquerque to Belen, then NM 47 diagonally to US 60, then east 21 miles to Mountainair. To travel the historic highway route (Turquoise Highway) from the north, take I-40 east from Albuquerque to NM 337, drive south 47 miles (76K) to junction with NM State Highway 55. Proceed right (west) on Hwy 55 about 16 miles (26 K). Turn right on Highway 60 and proceed one block to HQ. Information on the ruins & surrounding area is available here.

operatingHours.description:
Salinas Pueblo Missions National Monument is open 7 days a week year-round except for Thanksgiving, Christmas, and New Years Day.
Summer hours (April 1st - October 31st) for Mountainair Headquarters and Abó, Quarai and Gran Quivira sites are 10:00AM to 5:00PM daily. Winter hours (November 1st - March 31st) are 9:00AM to 4:00PM daily. 
For Visitor Center Hours for Abó, Quarai and Gran Quivira, please click the Visitor Centers tab below.
operatingHours.name: Headquarters, Abó, Quarai, and Gran Quivira

images.title: Quarai Mission In Spring
images.altText: Pink flowers and green foliage frame the roofless remains of a stone mission.
images.caption: Quarai Mission in Spring

images.title: Quarai Mission
images.altText: Stone walls of a roofless building rise into a bright blue sky.
images.caption: An overview of the Quarai Mission, seen from the west.

images.title: Annular Eclipse Seen From Gran Quivira
images.altText: An solar eclipse outlines an old stone structure at Salinas Pueblo Missions.
images.caption: An annular eclipse was visible from Gran Quivira in 2012. A special program allowed visitors to experience this amazing celestial event.

images.title: Kivas At Gran Quivira
images.altText: A paved path winds through the stone foundations of several old kivas.
images.caption: An overview of kivas at Gran Quivira

images.title: An Overview Of The Abó Mission
images.altText: Stone foundations of an old mission structure.
images.caption: An overview of the Abó Mission with the convento in the foreground.

images.title: Inside The Abó Church
images.altText: A path through stone walls of an old church.
images.caption: A view inside the Abó Church looking north. A nice carpet of grass is usually present during summer months.

data.weatherInfo: Salinas Pueblo Missions is located at an elevation of 6100-6500 ft (1860-1980 m) in an arid climate. Average annual rainfall is about 15 inches. Winters can be cold and snowy. Summer highs are above 90°F/32°C with cool evenings. The months of June-September often have thunderstorms. Flash flooding may occur in the area. Abó is especially prone to road closures as a result. Spring highs average 75°F/24°C. Fall temperatures are a little cooler. High winds often occur, which may result in trail closures.
data.name: Salinas Pueblo Missions

data.description: You can almost hear the whoops and cries of "All's set!" as trail hands hitched their oxen to freight wagons carrying cargo between western Missouri and Santa Fe, New Mexico. Follow the Santa Fe National Historic Trail through five states and you'll find adventure and evidence of past travelers who made this remarkable trip before you!
data.directionsInfo: You can visit many sites of the Santa Fe National Historic Trail over the 900-mile historic route that crosses five states.

operatingHours.description: There are many places of history and commemoration on the Santa Fe National Historic Trail to visit. Museums, interpretive centers, and historic sites provide information and interpretation. Please contact each site before you go to obtain current information on closures, changes in hours, and fees.
operatingHours.name: Santa Fe National Historic Trail

images.title: Cimarron National Grassland
images.altText: Warm light from the setting sun gives an orange glow to a rock bluff overlooking a grassland.
images.caption: Visit Cimarron National Grassland to experience the Santa Fe Trail.

images.title: Neosho River Crossing, Council Grove
images.altText: A wide river with green grass parks on the side.
images.caption: The Neosho River in Council Grove was an important crossing on the trail.

images.title: Bent's Old Fort National Historic Site, La Junta, Colorado
images.altText: emigrant wagons pulled by oxen and horses cross the prairie with people walking alongside
images.caption: After spending weeks crossing hundreds of miles of lonely and desolate prairie, a trading post appeared: a welcome respite where travelers could repair their wagon and trade for coffee, sugar, blankets, and ammunition.

images.title: Wagon Mound, Mora County, New Mexico
images.altText: desert landscape with a mountain that looks like a wagon from a distance, verdant green grasses
images.caption: Wagon Mound was a landmark on the Santa Fe Trail. Coming from Raton, New Mexico, travelers looked for this wagon-like hill to know that they were close to Santa Fe. Leave Interstate 25 at the village of Wagon Mound in Mora County to find this landmark.

images.title: Fort Union, New Mexico
images.altText: A stone path leads into the distance next to adobe ruins.
images.caption: The Santa Fe Trail traverses through Fort Union.

data.weatherInfo: Due to the length of the Santa Fe National Historic Trail, be sure to consult local weather sources for the region you'll be visiting. Check out the forecast with the National Weather Service and search for the area you'd like to visit: weather.gov
data.name: Santa Fe

multimedia.title: Pawnee Rock State Historic Site – Place to visit on the Santa Fe National Historic Trail
Black Jack Ruts – Place to visit on the Santa Fe National Historic Trail

data.description: About 1.2 million years ago, a spectacular volcanic eruption created a 14-mile-wide circular depression in the earth now known as Valles Caldera. The preserve is known for its huge mountain meadows, abundant wildlife, and meandering streams. The area also preserves the homeland of ancestral native peoples and embraces a rich ranching history.

entranceFees.description: The entrance fee for a private vehicle covers seven consecutive days of entrance to Valles Caldera National Preserve.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Private Vehicle

entranceFees.description: The entrance fee for motorcycles covers seven consecutive days of entrance to Valles Caldera National Preserve.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: The per-person entrance fee covers seven consecutive days of entrance to Valles Caldera National Preserve.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Per Person

entrancePasses.description: Beginning January 1, 2025, visitors may purchase an annual park pass for Valles Caldera National Preserve.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Entrance - Park

data.directionsInfo: From Jemez Springs, NM: Follow NM-4 north. The Preserve is about 22 miles from Jemez Springs. Look for the Main Gate and signs at Mile Marker 39.2. From Los Alamos, NM: Take Trinity Drive to Diamond. Take a left on Diamond, then a right on West Jemez Road to the intersection with NM-4. Take a right [away from Bandelier National Monument], following the highway up and into the Jemez Mountains. The Preserve is 18 miles up NM-4 from Los Alamos. Look for the Main Gate and signs at Mile Marker 39.2.

operatingHours.description: Valle Grande Main Entrance is located at mile marker 39.2 along New Mexico Highway 4.
operatingHours.name: Valle Grande Main Entrance

images.title: Wide Open Views of Valles Caldera
images.altText: Scattered clouds over landscape view of winding river and brown grasslands
images.caption: The views of Valles Caldera are some of nature's best

images.title: Coyote on Thin Ice
images.altText: A coyote walks across a frozen stream in a snowy valley.
images.caption: A coyote crossing the frozen East Fork Jemez River

images.title: San Antonio Cabin
images.altText: San Antonio cabin under a mostly cloudy sky
images.caption: San Antonio Cabin often housed cowboys when the preserve was privately-owned and operating as a ranch.

images.title: Elk Bulls Fighting
images.altText: Two bull elk fighting.
images.caption: The fall elk rut is a big attraction for visitors to see bull elk sparing and to hear the bulls bugle.

images.title: East Fork
images.altText: A narrow stream meanders through a montane grassland.
images.caption: The East Fork Jemez River overlook is one of the first places that visitors stop for photos.

data.weatherInfo: Each season offers a different experience: lush springs, moderate summers, golden falls, and snowy winters. Average temperatures are 22°F (-6 C) in January and 60°F (16 C) in July. Temperature extremes range from a high of 84°F (29 C) in summer to -30°F (-34C) in winter. Precipitation is heavier during summer monsoon rains (thunderstorms) in July and August and winter snowstorms in December through March. Higher elevation lends to much cooler temperatures than nearby Albuquerque.
data.name: Valles Caldera

multimedia.title: Night Sky from the Cabin District

data.description: Rising from the heart of the Tularosa Basin is one of the world's great natural wonders - the glistening white sands of New Mexico. Great wave-like dunes of gypsum sand have engulfed 275 square miles of desert, creating the world's largest gypsum dunefield. White Sands National Park preserves a major portion of this unique dunefield, along with the plants and animals that live here.

entranceFees.description: Per vehicle fee is charged to visitors for entry by a single, private non-commercial vehicle. Entrance fees are valid for reentry for seven consecutive days from the date of purchase.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Private Vehicle

entranceFees.description: Per person fee is charged to visitors for entry by means other than a single, private non-commercial vehicle. This includes, but is not limited to, individuals who enter the park by walking and bicycling. Entrance fees are valid for reentry for seven consecutive days from the date of purchase.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Per Person

entranceFees.description: Entrance fees are valid for entry for seven consecutive days from the date of purchase.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: Commercial bus/van tours are charged a flat rate based on the capacity of the vehicle (not the number of persons on board).
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Van

entranceFees.description: Commercial bus/van tours are charged a flat rate based on the capacity of the vehicle (not the number of persons on board).
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Mini-bus

entranceFees.description: Commercial bus/van tours are charged a flat rate based on the capacity of the vehicle (not the number of persons on board).
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Motor Coach

entrancePasses.description: This pass admits the pass holder and three persons (16 years and older) in a private non-commercial vehicle into the park for free for a period of one year from month of purchase. It can only be purchased at the entrance station to White Sands National Park. This pass does not apply to special use fees, such as camping and interpretive program fees.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Entrance - Park

data.directionsInfo: White Sands National Park is located off of US Highway 70 between the cities of Las Cruces and Alamogordo. The park is about 15 miles west of Alamogordo and 52 miles east of Las Cruces.

operatingHours.description: The park gates always open at 7:00 am with closing hours changing with sunset. The park closes 30 minutes after local sunset. Local sunset is 8 minutes earlier than Alamogordo's predicted sunset. Sunset times can be found at https://sunrise-sunset.org/us/alamogordo-nm
operatingHours.name: Standard Park Hours

images.title: Sunset
images.altText: White dunes in foreground with sun setting behind mountain.
images.caption: Sunsets are one of the most popular times to visit White Sands. Visitors can experience sunset every day of the year.

images.title: Aerial of Dunefield
images.altText: Aerial of white sand dunes.
images.caption: The dunes at White Sands cover 275 square miles of the Tularosa Basin.

images.title: Ripples
images.altText: Close up view of ripples on a dune.
images.caption: The wind shapes and moves the dunes as a whole but gives each individual dune the texture of ripples.

images.title: Fall Colors
images.altText: Cottonwood trees with orange leaves.
images.caption: Fall is a wonderful time to visit as most of our plants with leaves change beautiful colors.

images.title: Shaded Dunes
images.altText: Grey shadows on dunes.
images.caption: As the sun changes its angle through the sky it allows shadow to roll across the dunes.

data.weatherInfo: Temperatures at White Sands vary greatly throughout the year. Summer time temperatures can be very hot. Winters are mild with cool evenings. Spring time is the windy season. Fall is very enjoyable with mild daytime and night time temperatures.
data.name: White Sands
